title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools focuses on improving students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. Character education in schools involves teaching, modeling, and practicing positive ethical character traits to promote a compassionate and responsible society. It increases students' self-esteem and reduces the risk of isolation or harm to others. Integrating character education into existing curriculum and daily activities helps foster students' development. Character education in schools integrates ethical values into curriculum and activities, promoting responsible individuals in a community. States and educational agencies are increasingly supporting character education initiatives for students' development. Agencies are promoting character education initiatives by providing access to effective methodologies, professional development opportunities, criteria for assessment, and networking opportunities. States and local educational agencies are coordinating the implementation of character education in schools with a central source of information. States and local educational agencies are coordinating the implementation of character education in schools, necessitating a central source of information on the effectiveness and impact of initiatives at the federal, state, and local levels. The Secretary is authorized to make a single 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, curricula, research, and assessment. Membership should be representative of various groups. The grant recipient must use funds to develop character education initiatives, resources, and curricula, with a commitment to promoting quality programs. The grant recipient must use funds to develop character education initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student motivation and behavior, promote schools as caring communities, and provide opportunities for students to practice character lessons. The character education initiatives should emphasize student motivation, behavior, and the development of schools as caring communities. They should also provide opportunities for students to practice character lessons, involve families and communities, emphasize leadership, service, and teamwork, and evaluate effectiveness. The grantee will evaluate the effectiveness of character education initiatives, including their impact on disciplinary referrals and teacher expectations. Grant funds will be used to disseminate information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, and methods. The curr_chunk provides information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, assessing effectiveness, integrating character education into educational content, and any other helpful topics for character educators. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, and videos, as well as a checklist for schools to assess character education programs. The grantee will provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, along with a checklist for schools to assess the appropriateness of character education curricula. Additionally, they will offer an index of websites related to character education and telephone assistance. The grantee must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing their progress in meeting these requirements. The grantee must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the progress of carrying out requirements in character education, including requests for information, unmet needs, and grant utilization. The grantee must submit an annual report detailing requests for information, unmet needs, and grant utilization, including who made requests and the types of information requested. Authorization of $750,000 for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 is provided. SEC. 3. GRANT TO CONDUCT CHARACTER EDUCATION RESEARCH. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives and their success are unknown, and the ongoing needs of schools with existing programs have not been identified. Efforts should be made to determine the extent to which schools are undertaking character education, the effectiveness of such efforts, and the extent to which Federal funds are being used to sponsor effective character education initiatives. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education in schools, its effectiveness, and the use of Federal funds for character education initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation, understanding of character education approaches, and experience in developing initiatives. The Secretary seeks expertise in evaluation, research, and character education approaches, with experience in developing initiatives and identifying quality programs, a record of research and publishing findings, and a connection with higher education. The grant recipient must have expertise in character education, research, and publishing findings, as well as a connection with higher education. The grant requirements include assessing schools' character education initiatives, categorizing approaches, and examining the use of federal and state funds. The grant recipient must assess character education initiatives in schools, categorize approaches, evaluate funding impact, and report outcomes to the Secretary annually. The grant recipient must assess character education initiatives in schools, categorize approaches, evaluate funding impact, and report outcomes to the Secretary annually through a detailed report. The curr_chunk discusses unmet and future information needs in character education and provides a detailed account of grant fund usage. Authorization of $700,000 for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 is provided. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "eligible organization" in this Act refers to a group of organizations meeting specific requirements, including being described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and being tax-exempt under section 501(a). The term "eligible organization" refers to a group meeting specific requirements, including being tax-exempt under section 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code and submitting a grant application to the Secretary as required. The term "local educational agency" is defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "school" refers to any elementary school as defined by the same Act. The term "agency" is defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and it refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "school" includes both elementary and secondary schools as defined by the same Act.
